cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course that explores the development, physiology and continually changing function of the nervous system as it relates to certain types of human behaviour. Critical analysis of scientific evidence is used to enrich learning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Neuroscience
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO120H1, BIO130H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be fully online via live webinar (using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra – accessed within Quercus) on Tuesdays and Thursdays 10am to 1pm (Eastern Time). 
Lectures and tutorials will be recorded for asynchronous viewing, but it is strongly recommended that all students “attend” online all lectures and tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in Health and Disease using an interdisciplinary approach that integrates bacteriology and virology with other aspects of human biology, including chronic disease and neoplasia. An exploration of the key concepts and approaches that are necessary for understanding the dynamic nexus of human health and disease. (Lab Fees: $40)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health and Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO120H1, BIO130H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be asynchronous: given as 2-hr online videos twice a week posted on Wednesdays and Fridays. Tutorials will be synchronous for one hour per week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hour 1 hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students will need access to PDF, PowerPoint and the ability to use blackboard collaborate for webinars.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: February 11, 2021: Time changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to classical and modern methods of genetic analysis. Topics include Mendelian genetics, the genetics of human population and disease, genomics, and applications of genetics to human society.
cmCourseInfo.title: General & Human Genetics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO120H1, BIO130H1, (CHM135H1/CHM139H1, CHM136H1/ CHM138H1)/ CHM151Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Lecture recordings consisting of voiced-over PowerPoint presentations will also be posted on Quercus.  Tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.  Exams and tutorial quizzes will be synchronous (live) and delivered online per the meeting schedule, or during a final assessment period. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: May 27, 2021: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: This neuroscience course focuses on higher brain functions and the mechanisms underlying human and animal behaviours. Topics may include the emerging role of the gut microbiome's impact on behaviour, pathogens that alter neuronal development and the biological basis of mindfulness and placebos. In addition, the impact that exercise and sleep play in modulating these behaviours are examined. Common experimental techniques used in neuroscience research such as brain imaging and cellular genetics are emphasized.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurobiology of Behaviour
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO230H1/BIO255H1, HMB200H1/ PSY290H1/ PSL300H1/ CJH332H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory and lecture course studying the structure of the cell, various tissues and organ systems. Emphasis is on functional morphology and the adaptive response (including the inflammatory reaction) by comparing histological sections of normal tissues and organs with common diseases including neoplasia, respiratory, and liver disease. (Lab Materials Fee: $27)
cmCourseInfo.title: Vertebrate Histology and Histopathology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: BIO230H1/ BIO255H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be asynchronous: given as 2-hr online videos twice a week posted on Wednesdays and Fridays. 

Tutorials are synchronous, Wednesdays and Fridays from 1:00pm to 3:00pm via Blackboard Collaborate. Live with the TAs and prof! Bell-Ringer Tests: synchronous, during their normal tutorial time.¾ There will be 2 timed exams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore the scientific basis and interdisciplinary healthcare practices of several diseases (diseases vary by year). Discuss current issues related to the biology and the impact of these diseases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Health & Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete,  HMB202H1/ HMB203H1/ HMB204H1, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, PSL300H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online, asynchronously. Wednesday there will be 1-2h live check-ins with the course instructor and/or TA. All sessions are recorded. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course engages students in the fundamental science of epidemiology applied to health and disease. After an introduction to various measures of health and disease, the scientific methods used to investigate, analyze, prevent and control health problems will be illustrated using social, biomedical and public health examples
cmCourseInfo.title: Epidemiology of Health & Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete, BIO120H1, BIO130H1/HST209H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone.

courses.name: International Research Project in Human Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: Your individual, independent research project is supervised by a faculty member in an approved university. This unique opportunity to conduct a lab-based research project is open to students in any Human Biology program. Coordinated by Centre for International Experience. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 8.5 FCEs including relevant courses in human biology.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course focuses on recent research into the neurobiology underlying human behaviour. A variety of normal and abnormal human behaviours are studied which may include: voluntary action; moral cognition; hedonism; aggression; mental health; addiction; the impact of the gut microbiome on brain development and health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Neurobiology of Behaviour
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB200H1, HMB300H1, HMB320H1/ANA300Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminar and theme based course examining the opportunity to apply basic knowledge of biological determinants of disease to designing health system interventions and informatics that can have a global impact in the near term.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Global Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to complementary and alternative medical therapies. Topics include, Traditional Chinese Medicine, Naturopathy, Ayurvedic, and Mind-Body Practices. Biological mechanisms will be emphasized and therapies will be critically analyzed from an evidence-based research perspective. Integrating alternative therapies into Western practices with a focus on personalized medicine will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Complementary & Integrative Medicine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, BCH210H1, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, HMB302H1/ HMB312H1/ HMB314H1/ HMB322H1/ HMB323H1/ HMB342H1, and HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

courses.name: The Biology of the Human Metallome

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: April 14, 2021: Course cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will discuss how heavy metals are integral to organ function through various biological pathways, the importance of metal regulation and control and its relationship with gene transcription. An introduction of metallo-therapeutics will also be featured, ranging from neurodegenerative therapies to cancer treatment.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Biology of the Human Metallome
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB265H1/BIO260H1, BIO230H1/ BIO255H1, BCH210H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment, here: https://www.hmb.utoronto.ca/summer__400. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

Delivery Instructions

Lectures are delivered online asynchronously. There will be live virtual office hours through BB Collaborate. Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. Students may require access to a webcam and microphone. Students will require a media player for MP4 files.

courses.name: Brain Tumours: From Diagnosis to Treatment Effects

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on current insights in brain tumour etiology and pathology as well as treatment options and side-effects. Based on a seminar format, this course is highly discussion-based and collaborative in nature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Brain Tumours: From Diagnosis to Treatment Effects
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14.0 credits complete, PSL300H1, HMB302H1/HMB322H1/HMB300H1/CJH332H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description:
Vitamin and mineral deficiencies, termed ‘hidden hunger,’ affect about half the world’s population. Explore the global nature, catastrophic consequences, and causes of these deficiencies. Discuss formulation and implementation of international, national, and local policies to alleviate ‘hidden hunger’ especially in infants and young children. A service-learning opportunity is integrated. Students will be required to contribute to a local community organization while using course knowledge to develop a project or initiative beneficial to the organization and community.

a short application to enrol in this course is required. Information may be found via the Human Biology Program website.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Hidden Hunger
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, HMB302H1/ HMB303H1/ HMB312H1/ HMB314H1/ HMB322H1/ HMB323H1/ CJH332H1 (formerly CSB332H1)/ NFS382H1

notes.name: Course Note

Students need an internet connection and access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use online tools made available by the university, such as Office 365, Zoom and/or BB Collaborate. cmCourseInfo.description: Proper development of the human brain is essential for human health. This course will examine how neurodevelopment failures contribute to neurological disorders and diseases, such as epilepsy and autism. Current research from basic, translational, and clinical perspectives will be examined using case studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurodevelopmental Disorders and Diseases
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB200H1, HMB320H1/ANA300Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description:
A research project course for students enrolled in a Human Biology program, supervised by a faculty member appointed in a faculty or division at St. George Campus (Faculties of Arts & Science, Medicine, Engineering, Dalla Lana School of Public Health, etc.). Open to third and fourth year students.


Students are responsible for securing their own supervisor. Should a HMB Specialist require help securing a supervisor, the request must be made by email to the Human Biology Program Office no later than July 20 for Academic year projects and January 30 for Summer projects.


Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website.


Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Human Biology Program; please refer to the Human Biology Program website for more details
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students are not permitted to do a HMB research project concurrently with another research project
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 0.5 FCE or more in any statistics course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

To enrol in this course, please see current information on the HMB website here: https://www.hmb.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/curriculum-course-info/research-projects-human-biology. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Workshops are held over the F and S terms for students, and will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).

For students enrolled in the online-only HMB496/9Y1, if Public Health and institutional guidelines allow, and by mutual agreement of the student and faculty supervisor, in-person meetings may be arranged.

Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website.


Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

The delivery of independent research courses is unique to each project. The project is typically designed by the supervisor with input from the student. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Workshops are held over the F and S terms for students, and will be live-streamed and recorded (permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance).
